flow.descriptionCdata:
9dc2a782-1124-4d98-89f8-14498599b405.03384642-be13-4d6b-934a-2a40827d0e77.description=
Checks to see whether a String matches a specific rule.
If the  input value is 'RegEx' , the  input value needs to be a regular expression like \: '^-?\d+(([\.,]\d+)?)+$'. The  input is the actual String to check if it matches the  expression.

Inputs\:
    matchType - The type of match to perform.
    toMatch - The String to check if it matches another string.
    matchTo - The String to match against. 
    ignoreCase - A Boolean value specifying  whether to ignore case during matching.

Results\:
    returnResult - This is the primary output. Returns "Matches" if the String matched. Otherwise, returns  "Does not Match."

Responses\:
    success - The operation completed successfully. The String matched.
    failure - The operation completed unsuccessfully. The most likely reason is that the String did not match.
9dc2a782-1124-4d98-89f8-14498599b405.05200b44-73f0-43b5-a54f-115145cf15a4.description=Retrieves the server(s) ServerVO properties Inputs\: coreHost - The DNS name or IP Address of your SAS core. corePort - The port to Connect to your SAS core on. coreProtocol - The protocol to connect to your SAS core with. Either HTTP or HTTPS. coreUsername - The username for host. corePassword - The password for host. coreVersion - The version of SAS to use. agent - The agent name search string (can be a partial name and multiple return results can be returned Responses\: success - retrieved successfully failure - failed to retrieve data Returns\: createdBy - The name of the user who created this object. createdDate - The date that this object was created. id - The unique ID of this object. createdBy - The name of the user who created this object. createdDate - The date that this object was created. dirtyAttributes - A ; delimited list of attributes that are dirty (Modified and not yet fully propagated). modifiedBy - The user who last modified this object. modifiedDate - The date that this object was last modified on. description - The description of this object. hostname - The DNS hostname of this object. model - The model of this object. osVersion - The version of the OS running on the object. primaryIP - The primary IP address of this object. serialNumber - This object's serial number. manufacturer - The manufacturer of this object. name - The name of this object version - The version of this object codeset - The Code set of this object. customerName - The name of the customer this object was created for. defaultGW - The default gateway used when accessing this object. discoveredDate - The date when this object was first discovered. facilityName - The name of the facility housing this object. locale - The locale this object is in. lockComment - The comment on this object's locked. NOTE\: object may not be locked. lockDate - The date this object was last locked. lockUser - The user who locked this object last. isLocked - A boolean value specifying whether or not this object is currently locked. loopbackIP - The loopback ip address used by this object. managementIP - The management ip address used by this object. mid - mid The server's management identifier. NetBIOSName - The full netBIOS (Windows networking) name for this object. lifecycle - The state in the Opsware lifecycle that this object is currently in. origin - The origin of the managed server. ASSIMILATED or PROVISIONED osFlavor - The flavor of the OS running on this object. For example\: Windows. osSPVersion - The service pack version of the OS running on the object. peerIP - The managed server's peer IP address. platformName - The name of the platform. previousSWRegDate -The last time the Opsware agent reported the installed software on the server. realmName - The name of the realm this object is in. stage - The stage of the managed server. state - The current state of the managed server\: OK, UNREACHABLE or MAINTENANCE use - The intended use of the managed server (i.e. its role in a deployment)\: DEVELOPMENT, STAGING, PRODUCTION or UNKNOWN. virtualizationType - The virtualization type. 9dc2a782-1124-4d98-89f8-14498599b405.284bab77-874e-4565-9aa4-66f255c6332f.description=Attaches a software policy to a server. Inputs\: coreHost - The DNS name or IP Address of your SAS core. corePort - The port to Connect to your SAS core on. coreProtocol - The protocol to connect to your SAS core with. Either HTTP or HTTPS. coreUsername - The username for host. corePassword - The password for host. coreVersion - The version of SAS to use. serverName - Name of the server to attach the policy to. policyName - Name of the policy to attach. policyID - ID of the policy to attach. serverID - ID of the server to attach the policy to. Responses\: success - The operation completed successfully. failure - Something went wrong. 9dc2a782-1124-4d98-89f8-14498599b405.3b855a82-8063-47f5-a87f-75cffb14e6ea.prompt=Enter a value for agent 9dc2a782-1124-4d98-89f8-14498599b405.45df4afc-d3a5-4b6e-bf0a-42452e70551d.prompt=Enter a value for jobID 9dc2a782-1124-4d98-89f8-14498599b405.467ac01d-1916-4654-b99f-009fc465f426.description=
Adds a flow variable into the local context (available to itself and child flows only)

Input Parameters\:
keyName - the name of the flow variable to use
myValue - the value to assign the flow variable

Responses\:
success - assigned the flow variable

Scriptlet Example\:
[$scriptletContext putGlobal\: $keyName, $myValue];
9dc2a782-1124-4d98-89f8-14498599b405.4fe62cd0-708f-4958-9b61-b6eb9bc8fc4f.description=
Adds a flow variable into the local context (available to itself and child flows only)

Input Parameters\:
keyName - the name of the flow variable to use
myValue - the value to assign the flow variable

Responses\:
success - assigned the flow variable

Scriptlet Example\:
[$scriptletContext putGlobal\: $keyName, $myValue];
9dc2a782-1124-4d98-89f8-14498599b405.65f37293-1fb1-46d3-9d8c-6f7d1fa22d36.prompt=Enter the SAS version used\: 9dc2a782-1124-4d98-89f8-14498599b405.6843e659-9197-4d39-9eec-056810811d48.description=
Service to perform an HTTP POST via the Java HTTP Client.

Inputs\:
    url - The URL to send the HTTP POST request to.
    username - The username to use for authentication to the URL. For NTLM authentication, the required format is domain\user.
    password - The password to use for authentication to the URL.
    authType - The authentication type that this operation uses when trying to execute the request on the target server.
Valid values\: basic, form, digest, ntlm, kerberos, anonymous (no authentication).
Default value\: anonymous - authentication not used when executing the request.
    kerberosConfFile - The path to the Kerberos configuration file. If this input is empty the kdc (Key Distribution Center) and realm will get their values from the full domain name which is obtained from the url of the web server.
    postDocument - The raw text to be posted by this operation using the HTTP POST method. This does not have to be a path to a file/document on the disk.
    contentType - The content type that should be set in the request header, representing the MIME-type of the data in the message body.
Examples\: "text/html", "text/html; charset\=UTF-8", "application/x-www-form-urlencoded".
    characterSet - The character encoding of the text to be posted. If not specified this will be taken from the 'charset' field that can be specified in the contentType input. If the 'charset' field is absent it will be set to ISO-8859-1 by default.
    timeout - The number of milliseconds to wait for a connection to be established. This input should be assigned a value greater than or equal to zero. A timeout value of zero is an infinite timeout.
Default value\: 0.
    useCookies - If true, enables cookie tracking. Cookies will be stored between consecutive calls. This is a boolean input. If a non-boolean value is specified, it will take the default value.
Default value\: true.
    proxy - The hostname or IP address of a computer that acts as a proxy server.
    proxyPort - The port on the proxy server to connect to.
    proxyUsername - The username to use when connecting to the proxy server.
    proxyPassword - The password to use when connecting to the proxy server.
    encodeURL - If true, automatically encodes the URL. This is a boolean input. If a non-boolean value is specified, it will take the default value.
Default value\: false.
    trustAllRoots - If true, enables weak security over SSL. A SSL certificate is trusted even if no trusted CA issued it.
Default value\: false.
    keystore - URL of the keystore file or local path to it (e.g. %JAVA_HOME%/jre/lib/security/cacerts). It may be empty if HTTPS client  authentication is not to be used.
    keystorePassword - Password to unlock the keystore.
    trustKeystore - URL of the truststore file or local path to it (e.g. %JAVA_HOME%/jre/lib/security/cacerts). It may be empty if HTTPS server authentication is not to be used.
    trustPassword - Password to unlock the truststore.

Results\: 
    resultText - The raw result of the operation.
    document - The complete document returned by the Http Client Post Raw operation.
    PageLoadTimeInMS - The number of milliseconds taken for the page to load.
    ResponseTimeInMS - The number of milliseconds taken before the server responded.
    exception - If an error occurred, the stack trace of the thrown error.
    errorMessage - If an error occurred, an informational message that may help determine the cause of the error.
    httpResult - A textual reason phrase describing the HTTP response that the web server returned for the request that this operation sent. This result contains the HTTP response status (e.g. SUCCESS, PAGE_NOT_FOUND, UNAUTHORIZED, FORBIDDEN, ...) or GENERAL_ERROR in case the HTTP request could not be executed by the operation.

Responses\:
    success - The POST command completed.
    PAGE_NOT_FOUND - The URL specified to POST from could not be found.
    INFORMATIONAL - The POST was not fully processed, the server responded with an informational response.
    REDIRECTION - The specified URL has moved.
    failure - The POST operation failed.

Notes\:
1. You can use keytool to import an ssl certificate in a keystore. For example to import a certificate in the Java cacerts keystore you should run\: keytool -import -file c\:/../.cer -alias  -keystore %JAVA_HOME%/jre/lib/security/cacerts -keystorepass changeit. If the keystore does not exist the command will try to create a new one containing only your certificate.
2. You can use keytool to create a certificate chain through the following command\: 
   keytool -genkey -dname "cn\=Mark Jones, ou\=JavaSoft, o\=Sun, c\=US" 
      -alias business -keypass kpi135 -keystore C\:\working\mykeystore 
      -storepass ab987c -validity 180
It creates a certificate chain in a new keystore containing only one certificate. This command is useful in case of ssl client authentication because the KeyManager ignores any certificates which are not included in a certificate chain.
3. If trustAllRoots \= false and trustKeystore is empty, the operation will try to use the default trust store with the password "changeit". (i.e.  %JAVA_HOME%/jre/lib/security/cacerts) 
4. If the authentication type is Kerberos you might need to add a SPN for the web server's computer account. In order to do this, you can use ADUC (Active Directory Users and Computers) with "Advanced Features" enabled. Just go to the web server's computer account (e.g. CN\=,CN\=Computers,DC\=domain,DC\=com), open the "Properties" window and hit the "Attribute Editor" tab. There should be an attribute named "servicePrincipalName". Observe the values of this attribute and add your SPN if not present (e.g. HTTP/\:port).
5. If you need to specify the request header fields, the operation accepts hidden input whose name begins with "header_".  You can add multiple headers.  For example, add an input name called "header_Content-Type" with a value as "text/html" and/or an input name called "header_Content-Length" with a value as "348".  The operation will strip off the "header_" prefix from the input name first, and the "Content-Type" and/or "Content-Length" header should be created with the value you specify.
6. Currently, the only supported application server when using form-based authentication is Apache Tomcat.
9dc2a782-1124-4d98-89f8-14498599b405.72b4cf0e-38f3-456b-97a6-d6d42219f9fd.prompt=Enter the SAS version used\: 9dc2a782-1124-4d98-89f8-14498599b405.78b5f827-1289-406e-aa6b-e84bd6122425.prompt=Enter the SAS version used\: 9dc2a782-1124-4d98-89f8-14498599b405.7ae366c9-55b5-44bd-8b7d-66ac6011367d.prompt=Enter a value for jobID 9dc2a782-1124-4d98-89f8-14498599b405.8484c4b3-c4a5-486b-8eb5-7224884535f5.description=Counts from one number to another number. 
Inputs\:
from - The number to start counting at.
to - The number to count to.
incrementBy - The number to increment by while counting. If unspecified this is 1. If you wanted to count 2,4,6,8 this would be 2.
reset - If true, then the counter will restart counting from the beginning.

NOTE\: These values must be between -9223372036854775808 and 9223372036854775807

Returns\:
The number that was just counted.

Note\: the primary result is resultString, Result can also be used. result (All lower case) should not be used as it is the response code.

Responses\:
has more - Not yet done counting.
no more - Done counting. This will only be returned once, then counting restarts.
failure - Something went wrong.
9dc2a782-1124-4d98-89f8-14498599b405.8b4984be-1cd2-4509-b51b-27c0d3a4ef78.prompt=Enter a value for serverID 9dc2a782-1124-4d98-89f8-14498599b405.a10a6a26-d583-4ff1-a48a-24bb0294ce50.description=
This operation can be used to find the SA version in the form of 'sasXXX' (Similar to the entries in the Selection List 'SAS Version'). Output of this operations  could be mapped to the input parameter 'coreVersion' which is used in other SA Operations. For SA version 6.x, this operation is not supported. For other SA versions, if the output variable 'coreVersion' is reported with 'UNKNOWN', then user is recommended to manually find the SA version to use in other SA Operations.

Inputs\:
coreHost - IP Address or DNS name of the SA Web Service.
corePort - HTTP(S) port of SA Web Service. By default it is '443'.
coreProtocol - HTTP / HTTPS. By default it is 'HTTPS'.
coreUsername - Username of the SA.
corePassword - Password of SA user.

Outputs\:
status - Operation completion Status.
coreVersion - SA version.  It could be one of [sas7, sas75, sas78, sas9, sas91, UNKNOWN].

Responses\:
success - retrieved successfully
failure - failed to retrieve data
9dc2a782-1124-4d98-89f8-14498599b405.bcdc35ba-95bc-4f1e-b4c4-226c00b002f5.prompt=Enter a value for toMatch 9dc2a782-1124-4d98-89f8-14498599b405.d9cc7953-ac11-4d8b-8070-78c085e39f9a.prompt=Enter the SAS version used\: 9dc2a782-1124-4d98-89f8-14498599b405.ddc893ed-0885-4654-9f82-831ada57b5b1.description=Checks to see if a job is completed or not Inputs\: coreHost - The DNS name or IP Address of your SAS core. corePort - The port to Connect to your SAS core on. coreProtocol - The protocol to connect to your SAS core with. Either HTTP or HTTPS. coreUsername - The username for host. corePassword - The password for host. coreVersion - The version of SAS to use. jobID - the id of the job Responses\: running - job is still running completed - job has completed or is terminated in error failure - failed to retrieve data 9dc2a782-1124-4d98-89f8-14498599b405.description=
This workflow remediates the DMA agent policy to the target server and adds it to the target organization on DMA

Inputs\:

coreHost		- The DNS name or IP address of the the SA host
corePort		- The port to connect to SA core
coreUsername	- The username for the  HP SA host
corePassword	- The password for the  HP SA host
organizationId	- Id of the target organization on DMA
targetHostname	- DNS name of the target server to be added to the DMA organization

Responses\:
success - Workflow completed successfully.
failure - Something went wrong.
9dc2a782-1124-4d98-89f8-14498599b405.f49f3652-0b1d-4464-8c85-4861b120e7b8.description=Starts a full remediation of the specified server. If wait is specified, this operation will wait for the remediation to complete. Instead of full remediation, If the user wants to remediate the given server with only set of Software Policies, then those policies should be given in the input parameter 'swPolicies'. Inputs\: coreHost - The DNS name or IP Address of your SAS core. corePort - The port to Connect to your SAS core on. coreProtocol - The protocol to connect to your SAS core with. Either HTTP or HTTPS. coreUsername - The username for host. corePassword - The password for host. coreVersion - The version of SAS to use. agent - Name of the server to remediate now. wait - An integer value specifying How many milliseconds should be waited for the job to finish. If not specified the job is started, but may not have finished. swPolicies - [Optional] Name/Complete folder path of the software policies (separated by comma). If the given Software Policy is not already attached to the server, then it will be attached before remediation. Responses\: success - The operation completed successfully. failure - Something went wrong. Returns\: returnResult - The id of the job created. 9dc2a782-1124-4d98-89f8-14498599b405.f8f687c8-2571-4aa4-ac7b-cd66466a75e9.description=Waits for the job to reach a specific state. If no state is specified, then this will wait for the job to reach an end state. Inputs\: coreHost - The DNS name or IP Address of your SAS core. corePort - The port to Connect to your SAS core on. coreProtocol - The protocol to connect to your SAS core with. Either HTTP or HTTPS. coreUsername - The username for host. corePassword - The password for host. coreVersion - The version of SAS to use. jobID - the id of the job status - The status to wait for the job to reach. If none is specified this will wait until the job is no longer running. timeout - The maximum number of milliseconds to wait for the job. If not specified, 1 hour is used. Responses\: failure - Something went wrong. success - The operation completed successfully.
flow.name: Add Server to Organization
